# importing all the necessary stuff
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from matplotlib import pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
!pip install chart-studio
import chart_studio.plotly as py
import cufflinks as cf
import plotly.graph_objs as go
%matplotlib inline

from plotly.offline import download_plotlyjs, plot, init_notebook_mode, iplot
init_notebook_mode(connected=True)# initiate notebook for offline plot
cf.go_offline()

# Input data files are available in the read-only "../input/" directory
# For example, running this (by clicking run or pressing Shift+Enter) will list all files under the input directory

import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

source.d9b98b9d:
colors = ["#809fff", "#66ff66"]
trace = go.Pie(labels=["Movies", "Tv Show"], 
               values=[movies_count.type.count(), tvshows_count.type.count()],
               hoverinfo="label+percent", textinfo="label+percent", marker=dict(colors=colors,
                line=dict(color="#2d2d2d", width=2)))

fig = go.Figure(data=[trace])
iplot(fig)
source.82dcd438:
trace = go.Bar(x=netflix_df_counts.index[:15], y=netflix_df_counts, marker=dict(
                  opacity=0.8,
                  color=np.arange(15)
              ))
fig = go.Figure(data=[trace])

fig.update_layout(title="Top 15 Countries by Content")
fig.update_xaxes(title="Country")
fig.update_yaxes(title="Count")

iplot(fig)
source.aae1c47b:
trace = go.Pie(labels=netflix_director_counts.index[:10], values=netflix_director_counts,
               hoverinfo="label+percent", textinfo="label")

fig = go.Figure(data=[trace])
fig.update_layout(title="Director by % Content")

iplot(fig)

source.30756f9a:
# movie duration distribution
plt.figure(figsize=(10,8))
sns.set_style("darkgrid")
sns.kdeplot(data=movies_count["duration"], shade=True)
source.e1363413:
trace = go.Bar(x=netflix_df.rating.value_counts().index[:10], y=netflix_df.rating.value_counts(),
               marker=dict(
                  opacity=0.8,
                  color=np.arange(10)
              ))
fig = go.Figure(data=[trace])

fig.update_layout(title="Maximum Content By Ratings")
fig.update_xaxes(title="Ratings")
fig.update_yaxes(title="Content Count")

iplot(fig)
source.48efc130: # Content Produced On The Basis Of Ratings
source.6bc73e9c: # Movies and TV Shows Content Comparison
source.d5fc6d89: **Kindly Upvote if you like the notebook and share possible improvements in the comments.**
source.05ac86d0: First convert all the duration string values to integer
source.f137a1ee: Let's look at the null and missing values
source.c5ab03fa: **We can observe that netflix produces most of it's content in USA followed by India and UK**
source.6ca34c10: **From this we can clearly observe that there is a lot more Movies content than TV Shows.**
source.63323c64: # Comparison of Tv Shows and Movies
source.35dfbfc9: **We can observe that the maximum movies on netflix was of duration 80-100 minutes**
source.9ae5f43e: **we can observe maximum content produced is TV-MA which is *mature content* suitable for 18+ years.**
source.b242cef7: We have to drop rows with null values in directors as that might affect the pie plot
source.2816d46f: **We can observe the shift of content being produced by netflix in india from 2000-2020**
source.dc76eabc: It shows we have a lot of null values in director column followed by case, country and date_added.
